He started accepting orders and catering as an expansion of his services. Warlito's ultimate dream is to build a house to improve his family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy additional raw ingredients

loans.name: Zusette

texts.en:
Zusette works hard to support her family. She is married and has a fishing business in the Philippines.

She requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional fishnets and other fishing supplies.

Zusette has been in this business for 10 years now.

In the future, Zusette would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional fishnets and other fishing supplies

loans.name: Jati Indah Group

texts.en:
This is the fourth loan for the Jati Indah  group. They have decided to continue taking out loans since they still need financial support until they are able to continue their businesses with their own capital. With every sale of pork, they are saving to use venture capital. 

Ni Wayan will use her loan to purchase local piglets. She plans to sell the piglets for pig barbeques, since they require easier care than superior pigs and generate faster sales. She hopes her new plan can be more successful. Besides breeding pigs, Ni Wayan also works as a laborer helping other farmers to maintain their land.

loans.use: to purchase local piglets

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en: Analyn, 34 years old, is married and has two children. Analyn operates a store to gain income, selling grocery items to the people in her village. She manages her business well so that, in return, she will gain good profits. Analyn is sending her children to school so she needs to increase her income to pay their bills. She is now asking for additional capital to buy more merchandise. Analyn will buy assorted biscuits, breads, coffee, noodles and soft drinks. Analyn will continue developing her sales so that she will achieve economic stability someday.

loans.use: to buy assorted biscuits, breads, coffee, noodles and soft drinks

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en: Teresita has been operating a retail business in their village for over eight years. With this activity, she earns better income to sustain her needs and has successfully repaid her previous loan used for her business. She is thankful for her membership in GDMPC that helped her improve her business. Recently, she is taking a new loan to purchase an additional variety of grocery goods to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase an additional variety of grocery goods to sell

loans.name: Ma. Lourdes

texts.en:
Ma. Lourdes is a hardworking entrepreneur who has an agriculture business, farming vegetables in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 10,000 PHP through NWTF in order to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Ma. Lourdes successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.
NWTF is presenting Ma. Lourdes' business for funding of another loan in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Njira

texts.en:
Njira married and with four kids, two of whom attend school which is the reason of her hard work. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

Njira has operated a kiosk business from home for the past six years, selling to passers-by and neighbours. She faces a major challenge of theft in her business. 

With the KES 30,000 she wants to purchase iron sheets for the construction of her house. Her dream is to see her children get a better education and become important people in society.

loans.use: to purchase iron sheets for the construction of her house.

loans.name: Baby

texts.en: Baby has a live-in partner and she works hard to support her family. For the past 5 years, she has operated a general store business in the Philippines. Baby has requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell in her store. Baby would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Eric

texts.en:
Eric hails from the Western Part of Uganda and holds a Diploma in Theology. After school, Eric engaged in small business projects, besides his pastoral duties to his community, to enable him to supplement his income and support his family of two children and a wife who works as a community volunteer in Gabba, central Kampala, where they currently live. 

Eric was introduced to the business of selling clean energy cook stoves by sales agents from Impact Carbon, a renewable energy support organization and since then, he has never looked back. Recently he was introduced to UpEnergy, through which he has been able to sell cook stoves, raise part of the school fees for his children and offer more support to his family members.

Eric is looking to use the Kiva loan to expand his Renewable Energy Business. The loan will enable Eric to ensure availability of stock, which he currently can’t afford, so that he can extend and grow his business. With a successful running business Eric will be able to provide payment in installments to end-users, who cannot afford to pay the products at once. Thus demand will increase and Eric needs to have more energy-efficient products available. 

UpEnergy enables Eric to access financial support services like the Kiva loan and offers marketing support. UpEnergy is helping to eradicate poverty by enabling the youth to be part of a business that helps improve lives. 

The biggest benefit from using energy-efficient stoves for Eric is that it helps families to save money and time. The members of the community are able to save more money and time by using energy-efficient cook stoves, while people’s health will improve, too.

Eric hopes to build his own house and have a self-sustaining business that can enable him to save for his family's future.

loans.use: to pay for clean energy-efficient cook stoves to sell

loans.name: Rhoda

texts.en:
Rhoda is married and has six children. She manages a food canteen, cooking and selling food for snacks and daily meals. Through her business, Rhoda gains just enough income to cover her family's daily expenses and to also provide education for her children. 

Rhoda wants to continuously sell delicious foods so she is asking for additional capital of PHP 25,000 to buy more ingredients, pork meat and vegetables to cook and sell. Selling delicious foods will help her achieve more customers and good income as well.

loans.use: to buy more ingredients, pork meat and vegetables to cook and sell.

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
Angela is a hard-working woman. She is 17 years old and lives in the town of Mbarara, in the Mbarara region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. For the past three years, Angela has been working hard to manage her charcoal business, in which she sells charcoal. 

To help expand her business, Angela has requested a loan of UGX 800,000 (Ugandan shillings) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more charcoal and will help Angela to generate greater profits and provide for her family. Angela hopes that, in the future, she will be able to open up a big retail shop. 

Angela is a member of BRAC Uganda's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy up to date electric clippers and other salon equipment

loans.name: Angel

texts.en:
"Angel is 27 years old and lives in the town of Bombo in the Luwero region of Uganda. She is married and has 2 children with none of them currently in school. For the past 4 years, Angel has been working hard to manage her salon, which deals in hair dressing. 

To help expand her business, Angel has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy products like weaves,braids,hair lotion,spray, and will help Angel to generate greater profits and add stock to the salon. Angel hopes that in the future she will be able to increase stock. 

Angel is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Angel who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: buy products like weaves,braids,hair lotion,spray

loans.name: Dina

texts.en:
Dina is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a motorcycle rental business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to purchase gasoline and spare parts for her motorcycle.

Dina has been in this business for two years. Dina earns additional income from food and food-supplement vending.

Dina has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase gasoline and spare parts for her motorcycle.

loans.name: Annalisa

texts.en:
Annalisa is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a motorcycle transport business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to buy spare parts for her motorcycle transport business.

Annalisa has been in this business for 15 years. Annalisa earns additional income from manicures and pedicures.

Annalisa has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for the maintenance of her motorcycle.

loans.name: Frank

texts.en: Frank deals in the transport business whereby he transports people in a taxi from one place to another, alongside rentals in Hoima, Uganda.  He started this business to educate and take care of his family.  He hopes to grow his business and own more taxis on realizing how profitable the business is despite the challenge of stiff competition and high fuel prices.  He is acquiring credit to clear the balance of his vehicle.

loans.use: to clear the balance of his vehicle.

loans.name: Winnie

texts.en:
Winnie is 25 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married, and has one child. For the past three years, Winnie has been working hard to manage her poultry business, which sells chicken birds. 

To help expand  business, Winnie has requested a loan of 950,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more chicken feeds and birds, and will help winnie to generate greater profits and improve on her family's standard of living. Winnie hopes that in the future, she will be able to construct a poultry farm and a primary school. 

Winnie is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more chicken feed and birds

loans.name: Jati Sari Group

texts.en:
Jati Sari Group has repaid its loans from MUK. Repayment is not attended to by all members of the group, but left entirely to the board, where Ni Luh is head of the group and has full responsibility for the lending group.

Ni Luh has two children, and conducts daily life as a housewife.  She operates the pig business at her home. With the prior loan, Ni Luh successfully maintained two pigs with very good development and a successful sale with a net profit of 500,000 IDR.  This gain is used for the everyday expenses both in the kitchen and for her children. For the next period, the Jati Sari Group has continued the loans from MUK.

Jati Sari Group members, located at suburban residences, mostly have trading businesses and raise livestock. One is raising pigs. With the number of members at seven, the group got a loan 14,000,000 IDR. Ni Luh, the head of the group, is using the loan to buy three types of local pigs, which will be sold to pig fatteners. The pigs will be maintained for two months, then sold.  Profits from the sale will be set aside and the capital will be used to buy pigs again. 

Ni Luh hopes this effort will be smooth so that she can realize her dream of making her kitchen more spacious.

loans.use: to buy three types of local pigs.

loans.name: Zephania

texts.en: Zephania, a married man, lives in Hoima, Uganda.  He started a retail shop business in 2000 to improve his well-being. He gets additional income from produce, buying and selling maize. He hopes for business expansion but lacks enough capital and is acquiring a loan  to buy sugar, rice and salt to sell.

loans.use: to buy sugar, rice and salt to sell.

loans.name: Ethyl

texts.en: Ethyl is 29 years old, married, and has two young children. She is managing a small bakery in their village. She pays laborers who also help her in bread production. She has been in the business for four years. Her income goes for daily meals, electric bills, and labor costs. She hopes to increase her income and continue making delicious breads to sell. So, she is now asking for additional revolving capital of PHP 20,000 to buy flour, milk, sugar, margarine, and ingredients to make breads. Someday, she hopes to maintain good flow of business and achieve financial stability for the future education of her children.

loans.use: to buy flour, milk, sugar, margarine, and ingredients to make breads.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel lives in Hoima, Uganda. He is a 60-year-old hard-working man, married with seven children; four attend school. He started a retail shop business to meet daily expenses. He gets additional income from a bar. He hopes for business expansion and to educate his children. However, competition and limited capital hinder his business. 

Emmanuel will use the loan to buy sugar, salt, soap and other general merchandise and complete his permanent house.

loans.use: to buy sugar, salt, soap and other general merchandise and complete his permanent house.

loans.name: Ega

texts.en:
Ega is married with six children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

Ega operates a milk selling business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business.  Her dream is to establish a dairy business in the near future. 

With the Kshs 10,000, she wants to purchase  gallons of milk for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase  gallons of milk for resale

loans.name: Mnyazi

texts.en:
Mnyazi is married with eight children, two of whom attend school. Mnyazi operates a charcoal selling business.
She buys, packages, and sells hardwood charcoal.  She buys bags and polyurethane, packages the charcoal, and sells to small businesses in the zone. 

She needs this loan to buy charcoal because she is increasing her number of customers and needs to increase her amount of charcoal to meet their demand. Her greatest desire is to provide an education for her two children who attend school so that she can guarantee them a prosperous future.

loans.use: to buy charcoal for resale

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is married and has four children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Margaret has been operating a food selling business, making dumplings and flat breads for sale. She sells from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. With her KES 20,000 loan she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat and sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat and sugar.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is a married woman with children who still attend school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity, but not piped water.

She has operated a kiosk retail shop business for the past year, selling household consumables such as wheat flour, maize flour and sugar. She faces a major challenge of debtors taking long to repay loans. 

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour.

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita is 18 years old and lives in the town of Siroko in the Mbale region of Uganda. For the past three years, Rita has been working hard to manage her small clothing business, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her  business, Rita has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes for sale, and will help Rita to generate greater profits and buy food for the family. Rita hopes that in the future  will be able to buy a plot of land and build a house. 

Rita is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more clothes for sale

loans.name: Jonife

texts.en:
Jonife works hard to support her family. Jonife is single and has an egg vending business in the Philippines.

She requested a PHP 29,500 loan through NWTF to purchase more trays of eggs to sell.

Jonife has been in this business for 5 years now, and also earns additional income from farming rice.

In the future, Jonife would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more trays of eggs to sell.

loans.name: Priscillar

texts.en:
Priscillar is a married woman and has been blessed with one kid who attends school. She lives in her own house, which has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. 

Priscillar operates a poultry-selling business, which has been operational for over 4 years. She mentioned disease outbreak causing losses as a challenge in the business. Priscillar dreams of becoming a wholesaler of poultry in the future. 

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase chicks and poultry feed. She joined Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase chicks and poultry feed

loans.name: Marvin Alexander

texts.es:
Marvin es un joven trabajador de 26 años de edad,  solo estudió educación básica, está acompañado, tiene dos hijas y su pareja se dedica a la comercialización de mariscos


Marvin  se dedica a la pesca artesanal,  además conoce muy bien la producción de granos básicos. Marvin aprendió muy bien estos trabajos por un amigo suyo, ahora le está sirviendo mucho para mantener a su familia.

Él necesita el crédito para comprar un mejor equipo de pesca (mallas) porque las que tiene en este momento están bastante deterioradas.

Él sueña con que su  familia viva en buenas condiciones, y contar siempre con el apoyo de su pareja.
texts.en: Marvin is a young 26 year old worker who only has his basic education. He is married and has two children. Hie wife works selling seafood. Marvin works in traditional fishing and he also knows how to grow basic grains well. Marvin learned these trades from a friend of his and now they serve him well in supporting his family. He needs a loan to buy better fishing equipment (nets) because the ones he now has are in poor condition. His dream is for his family to live in good conditions and always be able to count on the support of his spouse.

loans.use: to buy better fishing equipment (nets).

loans.name: Eme

texts.en:
Eme is 54 years old and widowed with six children.

Eme works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to buy more groceries to sell in her general store.

Eme has borrowed and paid six loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for ten years and also earns an income from food vending.

Eme aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en:
Ofelia is 47 years old and married with six children, two of whom are in school.

She earns a living by pig fattening in the Philippines. Ofelia has been pig fattening for three years and also earns additional income from selling vegetables. She is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream of building and expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Bernarda Alicia

texts.es: Bernarda de 63 años de edad habita en vivienda propia junto a su hija y 3 nietas de 16, 12 y 8 años de edad. Ella es una mujer que se esfuerza todos los días por salir adelante junto a su familia y para ello realiza la venta de ropa en los mercados cercanos desde hace 3 años. Hace un año solicitó un crédito a FUSAI para invertir en su negocio de venta de ropa, lo cual le ha permitido mantenerlo activo por mucho más tiempo. En esta ocasión solicita  un nuevo crédito dado que la vivienda de Bernarda necesita que se le construya un muro de contención lo antes posible ya que corre el riesgo de que se le desborde por lo que necesita comprar materiales como:  bloques de cemento, arena, grava, hierro y cemento para construir un muro de contención en su vivienda.
texts.en:
Bernarda is 63 years old and lives in her own house together with her daughter and 3 grandchildren aged 8, 12 and 16 years old. She is a woman who makes an effort each day to get ahead together with her family. In order to do this she has been selling clothing in nearby markets for 3 years.

One year ago she requested a loan from FUSAI to invest in her clothing business and this allowed her to keep her business active for a long time. At this time she is requesting a new loan as Bernarda's house need a retaining wall built as soon as possible as it runs the risk of collapsing. So she needs to buy materials like cinder blocks, sand, gravel, re-bar and cement to construct a retaining wall for her house.

loans.use: to buy cinder blocks, sand, gravel, re-bar and cement to build a retaining wall for her house.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is a married woman with two children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Evelyn is 33 years old and has two children who are currently in school.

Evelyn has a rice and dried fish vending business in the Philippines. Evelyn requested a PHP 18,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of rice and box of dried fish to sell.

Evelyn has been in this business for 5 years. In the future, Evelyn would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of rice and boxes of dried fish to sell

loans.name: Frelene

texts.en: Frelene lives in Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur with her family. She has managed her own general store for over three years to make a living. She sustained the family's daily expenditures from her income and supported her children's education. She joined GDMPC recently and had borrowed a new loan to purchase more grocery goods to sell. She works to expand her business to ensure a better source of income for the family in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more grocery goods to sell

loans.name: Edessa

texts.en:
Edessa is a married woman with two children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Edessa is 37 years old and has one child who is currently in school.

Edessa has a video gaming machine rental business in the Philippines. Edessa requested a PHP 25,000 loan amount through NWTF to pay for electric bills and purchase spare parts for the maintenance of her business.

Edessa has been in this business for six years. In the future, Edessa would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to pay for electric bills and purchase spare parts for the maintenance of her business.

loans.name: Triyono

texts.en:
This is the story of Quini, daughter of Triyono: 
I have three half brothers and sisters. Two are in elementary school, and the youngest one is in kindergarten. Years ago, my father had been gone for a long time with no news at all. My mother had to live alone and take care of me. She decided to ask the court for a divorce. Now, she is remarried and has three more children. It’s hard for me to ask my stepfather to fund my studies since life is hard for him. His income as a laborer is far from enough to meet all of our daily needs. I planned to work to help my parents, but my education level is not good enough to do so. It’s hard for a junior high school graduate to get a good job. That’s why I’m glad I can join Kiva’s program: I hope I can get support to continue my studies.

loans.use: to pay for education fees at the vocational school

loans.name: Donna May

texts.en:
Donna May is 34 years old, married, and has two children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 29,500 PHP loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, soap, milk, sugar, eggs, canned goods, etc.

Donna May has borrowed and paid 18 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for five years and also earns an income from pre-paid mobile load.

Donna May aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like shampoo, soap, milk, sugar, eggs, canned goods, etc

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia is a married woman with two children, one of whom is currently in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Cecilia is 45 years old.

Cecilia has an internet cafe business in the Philippines. She requested a 10,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy an additional computer for her business.

Cecilia has been in this business for five years. In the future, Cecilia would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy an additional computer for her business

loans.name: Dillia

texts.en: Dillia works hard to support her family. She is married and has a business making plastic bags in the Philippines. Dillia requested a 11,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy more materials for her business. She has been in this business for 10 years now. Dillia would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more materials for making plastic bags

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou is 47 years old, married, and has four children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 18,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase additional inventory to sell like soap, milk, sugar, eggs, chips, etc.

Marilou has borrowed and paid 15 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 10 years and also earns an income from food vending.

She aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory to sell like soap, milk, sugar, eggs, chips, etc.

loans.name: Beverly

texts.en: As a married parent of two children, Beverly works hard to support her family. She has a fishing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from pig fattening. Beverly is borrowing PHP 13,000 through NWTF to purchase fishing net and other materials for her fishing business. Beverly has been sustaining her business activities through her past four loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream, to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase fishing net and other materials for her business.

loans.name: Ecelyn

texts.en: Ecelyn is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a buy and sell meat and frozen foods business in the Philippines.  She is borrowing PHP 30,000 through NWTF to purchase additional meat and frozen products to sell for her meat and frozen foods business. Ecelyn has been in this business for two years. She also earns more income from pig fattening. Ecelyn has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional meat and frozen products to sell.

loans.name: Melquiadas

texts.en: Melquiadas, a 52-year-old father of four, has operated his own rice mill services for over ten years. He also has a retail business of rice and corn grits, earning well for the family. He has joined GDMPC recently and has borrowed a new loan to cover maintenance costs for his rice mill equipment. Hoping to improve and expand his services, Melquiadas hopes to gain more returns from his investments to improve their living as well.

loans.use: to cover maintenance costs for his rice mill equipment.

loans.name: Flordeliza

texts.en: Flordeliza works hard to support her family. She is widowed and has a sewing business in the Philippines. Flordeliza has requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF to buy more materials like fabric, threads, zippers, etc. for her business. She has been in this business for 30 years now. Flordeliza would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more materials like fabric, threads, zippers, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Elkin Humberto

texts.es:
El señor Elkin es un agricultor de profesión pero se desempeña como lechero, desde muy joven realiza esta actividad y la ayuda del micro-crédito ha sido vital pues le ha permitido mejorar su producción al tener más vacas para ordeñar, esta actividad tiene puntos a favor y en contra, uno de los aspectos negativos es que el cuido de la vaca es muy costoso, otro es que necesita vacunas especiales, insumos para realizar inseminación artificial puesto que la vaca solo da leche cuando está preñada, y el costo de una nueva vaca es muy alto. 
Buscado mejorar su producción de leche y mejorar la calidad de vida de sus 4 hijos y parejas, contando con sus hijos tienen 16, 14, 10, 8 años de edad y que depende en su totalidad de el por lo que solicita un crédito el cual invertirá en la compra de una vaca, los preparativos para realizar la respectiva inseminación artificial, cuido de levante y vacunas.
texts.en:
Elkin's a farmer by profession but he works as a milk producer.  He has done this work from a very young age.  The help of micro-credit has been vital because it has allowed him to improve his production and have more cows to milk.

This job has positive and negative points.  One negative aspect is that caring for a cow is very costly.  Another is that he needs special vaccines and inputs for artificial insemination, because a cow only gives milk when it's pregnant, and the cost of a new cow is very high.

He's requesting a loan so he can improve his milk production and the quality of life of his wife and four children, ages 16, 14, 10, and 8, who depend on him completely.  He's going to invest in buying a cow, the preparations he needs for artificial insemination, care for raising, and vaccines.

loans.use: to buy a cow, inputs for artificial insemination, and vaccines

loans.name: Zulma Yanira

texts.es:
Zulma tiene 38 años de edad, tiene como nivel académico bachillerato, tiene dos hijos que están estudiando, Zulma realiza la actividad de comercio de frutas y verduras  con el apoyo de su esposo quien conoce muy bien esta actividad y la producción agrícola.

Desde hace 15 años, Zulma se dedica al comercio de frutas y verduras, lo aprendió gracias a una tía que se dedicaba a lo mismo, su esposo se involucra al igual que sus dos hijos.

Ella necesita el crédito para comprar fertilizante para la producción agrícola, comprará gramoxone y abono.

Ella sueña con que su familia viva en buenas condiciones, que sus hijos continúen estudiando hasta ser profesionales y tener siempre el apoyo de su esposo.
texts.en:
Zulma, 38, has a high school diploma.  She has two children who attend school.  Zulma sells fruits and vegetables with the help of her husband, who is very familiar with this job and agricultural production.

Zulma has sold fruits and vegetables for 15 years.  She learned this thanks to an aunt who worked in that field.  Her husband and her two children are involved.

She needs the loan to buy fertilizer for her crop.  She's going to buy gramoxone and soil amendments.

She dreams of her family having good living conditions, her children continuing to attend school until they become professionals, and always having her husband's support.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en: Deborah lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with six children and all of them go to school. She has no additional family members. She sells used shoes at the market. She sells to all kinds of people on a retail basis. She has been in this business for the last 14 years. She gets additional income from farming. She works for seven days a week. She has requested a loan from MCDT-SACCO of Ugandan shillings 400,000 to buy a bale of used shoes. Her major challenges include transportation and seasonality. Her goal and inspiration is to buy a plot of land. She lives in her own house and the family has no access to electricity and does not have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food and school fees.

loans.use: to buy a bale of used shoes to sell.

loans.name: Liezel

texts.en: Liezel is 28 and has two children. She helps her husband in operating their own farm for a living. For over five years working on their farm, she was able to sustain their needs and make savings for improving their house. She has joined GDMPC this year and is borrowing a new loan to purchase fertilizer to improve their farm. She wants to improve their living situation and be able to support their children’s future education.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer.

loans.name: Recheal's Group

texts.en:
Recheal's group is comprised of two hard-working women. Recheal is 16 years old and lives in the town of Kiyinda in the Mubende region of Uganda. She has no children. For the past 6 months, she has been working hard to manage her tailoring business, which sews clothes. 

To help expand her business, Recheal has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy materials for making more clothes, and will help her to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her young siblings. Recheal hopes that in the future she will be able to own a salon. 

Recheal is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy materials for making more clothes

loans.name: Azena

texts.en:
Azena is 19 years old and lives in the town of Bungokho in the Mbale region of Uganda.  She is single and has one child. For the past three years, Azena has been working hard to manage her pharmacy, which sells drugs. 

To help expand her business, Azena has requested a loan of 950,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more medical drugs for sale, and will help Azena to generate greater profits and take care of her child, since she is a single mother. Azena hopes that in the future, she will be able to open up a sick bay and another pharmacy in town. 

Azena is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more medical drugs for sale.

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Ester is a hard-working woman. She is 16 years old and lives in the town of Kiyinda in the Mubende region of Uganda. She has no children. For the past 3 months, she has been working hard to manage her food stall, which sells fresh food. To help expand her business, Ester has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy Irish potatoes, sweet potatoes, cassava, and yams, and will help Ester to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her siblings. Ester hopes that in the future she will be able to join a tailoring course. 

Ester is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy Irish potatoes, sweet potatoes, cassava, and yams

loans.name: Florence's Group

texts.en:
Florence's group is comprised of three hard-working women. Florence is 16 years old and lives in the town of Kiyinda in the Mubende region of Uganda. She has no children. For the past year, she has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells rice, sugar, soap, and curry powder. 

To help expand her business, Florence has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more stock of rice, sugar, soap, and curry powder, and will help her to generate greater profits and educate her siblings. She hopes that in the future she will be able to become a nurse. 

Florence is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more stock of rice, sugar, soap, and curry powder

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia is 52 years old and married with three children. She is in the agricultural business of raising livestock in the Philippines. Cecilia has requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional livestock and other supplies for her business. She has been raising livestock for 12 years now, and has borrowed six times in the past from NWTF to sustain it. In the future, Cecilia would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional livestock and other supplies for her business

loans.name: Jambo

texts.en:
Jambo is married and has three children, two of whom attend school. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

He operates a goat  selling business, selling at the market to his neighbours and passersby. He faces a major challenge of seasonality in his business. His dream is to establish a rental house in the near future. 

With the KES 50,000 he wants to purchase goats for resale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase goats for resale.

loans.name: Ahmed

texts.en:
Ahmed is married and has four children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Ahmed operates a food-selling business, making dumplings and flat bread to sell. She sells from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the KES 30,000 Ahmed wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat and sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat and sugar

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with three children, all of whom go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She lives in a rented house, and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses includes food, medication, and school fees.

Florence operates a retail shop at the market. She has been in this business for the last 6 years, working seven days a week. She has requested a loan from MCDT - SACCO of UGX 700,000 to buy cooking oil, sugar, rice, beans, crates of soda, and peas. Her major business challenges include high transportation costs, which increase her operating costs. Florence's goal and inspiration is to buy a bigger refrigerator so she can serve her customers better.

loans.use: To buy beans, peas, cooking oil, sugar, sodas, and rice

loans.name: Nargiza

texts.ru: Наргиза 36-летний фермер из района Спитамен. Она замужняя женщина, у нее двое детей в возрасте 15 и 17 лет. Наргиза арендует 0,50 га орошаемого участка земли, на котором в данный момент посеяна кукуруза и в ближайшие дни она соберет урожай. Параллельно с растениеводством Наргиза собирается начать новый бизнес. Она выбрала сферу животноводства, так как для ведения этого бизнеса имеет хорошие условия. Корм для скотов она будет брать со своего земельного участка. А также при дворе ее дома имеется сарай для содержания скотов. Наргиза на запрашиваемую сумму кредита планирует купить один крупнорогатый скот хорошей породы. Она надеется на финансовую поддержку, так как своего капитала не хватает.
texts.en: Nargiza is a 36-year-old farmer from the Spitamen region. She is a married women. She has two children, ages 15 and 17. Nargiza rents 0.50 hectares of irrigated land, on which she plants corn and in the coming days she will gather the harvest. In parallel with the crops, Nargiza intends to start a new business. She decided on the sphere of animal husbandry since she has good conditions for running this business. Feed for the cattle she will get from her own plot of land. And similarly in the yard of her home she has a barn for tending the cattle. With the requested loan sum, Nargiza plans to buy one steer of a good breed. She hopes for financial support since her capital is not sufficient.

loans.use: to buy cattle

loans.name: Rihana

texts.en:
Rihana is 23 years old and lives in the town of Kisekende in the Mubende region of Uganda. She has three children, with one of them currently in school. For the past three years, Rihana has been working hard to manage her food stall, which sells snacks. 

To help expand her business, Rihana has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more flour, sugar, cooking oil and baking powder for making snacks, and will help Rihana to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her kids. Rihana hopes that in the future, she will be able to expand into a hotel. 

Rihana is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: buy more flour, sugar, cooking oil and baking powder for making snacks

loans.name: Edna

texts.en: Edna is a married, 46-year-old mother who manages a store for income. She is selling grocery items to the people in her village. She opens up her store as early as 6:00 a.m. in the morning until 6:00 p.m. in the afternoon. She would like to add more goods to sell. That is why she is asking for a loan of PHP 20,000 to buy sardines, noodles, coffee, soap and shampoo to sell. This will help increase sales capacity. She hopes to achieve better income and save a fund for education purposes. She hopes to continue giving good education to her children.

loans.use: to buy sardines, noodles, coffee, soap and shampoo to sell.

loans.name: Evans

texts.en:
Evans is an unmarried man. He describes himself as obedient. He operates a restaurant where he cooks food to sell. He has been involved in this business for 1 year. His business is located in a good area and he has good primary customers. He describes his biggest business challenge as a lack of funds. 

Evans will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy more stocks of ingredients for preparing food. His business goal is to be prosperous within 5 years. He hopes that in the future he will be successful. This is his first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of ingredients for preparing food

loans.name: Simion

texts.en: Simion is a married man. He has one child. He operates a retail business where he sells shoes. He has been involved in this business for five years. His business is located in a busy and populated area. He describes his biggest business challenge to be financial problems. He will use the KES 40,000 loan to buy more stock of shoes. His business goal is to be a wholesaler within five years. He hopes that in the future he will have a better life. This is his second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of shoes.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is a 42-year-old single woman who is taking care of three children and has been operating a stationery and bookshop business for two years, earning an income of KES 20,000 at the end of every month.

Nancy is now servicing her third loan of KES 30,000 with VisionFund Kenya and intends to use the entire amount to buy additional English, Science, and Maths textbooks, glue, sharpeners, pens, pencils, files, and stickers to add to her stock, which is running low.

Nancy plans to use the anticipated income to open a school library and hopes to become a famous supplier of books by opening another bookshop in a nearby town.

loans.use: To buy Maths, Science, and English textbooks and office supplies.

loans.name: Jinalyn

texts.en:
Jinalyn is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a buy and sell fish business in the Philippines. She is borrowing 13,000 PHP through NWTF to buy additional boxes of fish to sell for her buy and sell fish business. Jinalyn has been in this business for 10 years. Jinalyn earns more income from buying and selling crabs.

Jinalyn has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy additional boxes of fish to sell

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en: Melanie is 50 years old and married with six children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 17,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc. Melanie has borrowed and repaid five loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for five years and also earns an income from buying and selling coconut. Melanie aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college and for business expansion.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema appreciates for the previous loan that helped her expand her business.
Rehema operates a tablecloth, bedsheets and curtains selling business. She cites seasonality and stiff competition from other operators to be her major challenges. 

With the 20,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to pay for medical coverage for her family and buy households for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to pay for medical coverage for her family and buy household items for resale

loans.name: Damaris

texts.es:
Damaris, ha mejorado el inventario de su negocio, mantiene a sus clientes satisfechos, su situación económica no ha variado mucho, pero aun así cumple con el pago de sus cuotas, además tiene la oportunidad de dar a su familia una mejor alimentación diaria y apoya a sus hijos en los gastos de su educación.
Para mantener su negocio en el mercado y continuar mejorando las circunstancias familiares opta por un  nuevo préstamo con el que comprara diademas, prendedores para cabello, colas, binchas y otros productos con los que cubra las demandas de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Damaris has improved the inventory of her business, and keeps her customers satisfied. Her financial situation has not changed much, but now that she has completed paying her debts, she also has the opportunity to give her family better food daily and help her children with their educational expenses.

To maintain her business in the market and continue improving her familial circumstances she has decided on a new loan with which she will buy diadems, hairpins, hair trains, headbands, and other products, and will use those to cover the demands of her customers.

loans.use: to buy diadems, hairpins, hair trains, headbands, and other products with which she can cover the demands of her customers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a mobile phone and a solar charging set to provide vital farming information to his community

loans.name: Babrah

texts.en: Babrah is a single mother of six children, three of whom go to school. She also takes care of additional family members (a sister). She has a restaurant business and has been in this business for four years. She has applied for a loan of 300,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more  bunches of green bananas, beef, Irish potatoes, and fresh beans. She generates additional income from selling used shoes.  She works at the market seven days out of every week and sells on a retail basis.  Her major business challenges include transportation and defaulters.  She is aspiring to own a fully stocked restaurant and to buy a plot of land and build a house. She resides in a rented house and the family has access to electricity but not piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy green bananas, beef, fresh beans and irish potatoes

loans.name: Ritah

texts.en:
Ritah lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with five children and two go to school. She sells milk at the market, both retail and wholesale. She serves all kinds of people. She has been in this business for the last seven years. She takes care of additional family members. She works six days a week. 

Ritah has requested a loan of 400,000 from MCDT-SACCO to buy a jerrycan of milk, loaves of bread, and Blue band margarine. Her major challenge includes transportation and perishability of milk. She is aspiring of educating her children to university level and also buying another fridge. She lives in a rented house and the family has access to electricity but does not have access to piped water. Her major expense includes food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy a jerrycan of milk, loaves of bread, and Blueband margarine

loans.name: Uhuru Group

texts.en:
Flora, who is in her early fifties, is single and the mother of one daughter who is grown. Her daughter is blessed with a child who is at school. Flora also takes care of her sister's child, who is in secondary school. Despite being single, she manages to provide all of her family's needs through her general store and charcoal store businesses. She has been in these businesses for four years and is able to realize a fair profit each month. Flora's businesses operate from 9:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. daily.

This will be her twentieth loan request via Kiva partner's Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous credits, since repaid, to expand her business portfolio (when she started selling charcoal) and to replenish her general store. Flora managed to receive an extra income which she used to pay the school fees for her sister's child, who is now at "O" level. She covered her household expenses and bought a plot of land. She desires to be a successful mother and develop her plot with agriculture.

With her new loan request, Flora will use the funds to start an M-Pesa service as another project to maximize her income. She will share this loan with her loan group"Uhuru," which totals five members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to start M-PESA service as another project to maximize her income.

loans.name: Dorine

texts.en:
Dorine is 35 years old and married to Benard who supports the family of two children who are 11 and six years old. Dorine has been selling both new and secondhand clothes for the last six years, earning herself an income of KES 20,000.

She was introduced to VisionFund Kenya by a credit officer and is now servicing her fourth loan of KES 45,000. She intends to use this amount to add more stock of clothes to sell in her business to exceed her customers’ expectations.

See plans to use the anticipated income to expand her business and educate her children.

loans.use: to buy more stock of clothes to sell

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a married woman. She has four children with ages ranging from five to sixteen years. She describes herself to be business focused. 

She operates a retail business where she sells charcoal. She has been involved in this business for three years. Her business is located in an upcoming urban area. she describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate finances. 

She will use the KES 50,000 loan to buy more stock of charcoal. Her business goal is to have a stable business with branches in other towns within five years. 

She hopes that in the future, she will have a stable business that will sustain her family needs. This is her fourth loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of charcoal

loans.name: Charo

texts.en:
Charo is 50 years old. He is married, and together with his wife, he has been blessed with four children of ages between 18 and 2 years respectively. He currently supports eight people in his family.

Charo loves his business. He sells mangoes and has done this for the last 20 years, earning a monthly income of 20,000 KES (Kenyan shillings).

Charo has requested his third loan of 60,000 KES with VisionFund Kenya, which he will use to purchase sacks of mangoes for resale. It is important to note that Charo successfully repaid all his previous loans.

With the anticipated profits, Charo will be able to expand his business further. Believe it or not, Charo has a dream, and he is sure it shall come to pass. His dream is to someday buy himself either or all of these cars: RAV4, BMW or PRADO.

loans.use: to buy fruits for resale

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter has been in a retail shop business and sells charcoal as well. He has been in this business for the last 12 years and earns a monthly income of 10,000 KES (Kenyan shillings), which he uses to support his family. He is 48 years old, married and blessed with three children who all adults and have higher levels of education.

He has applied for his second loan of KES. 30,000 and will use the funds to buy more sugar, tea leaves, soft drinks and add more charcoal for sale.

Peter hopes to grow his business and pay fees for his children and be financially stable.

loans.use: to  buy more of sugar, tea leaves, soft drinks and add more charcoal for sale

loans.name: Maureen

texts.en:
Maureen is a married woman. She has two children. She describes herself to be focused. She operates a food stall where she cooks food for sale. She has been involved in this business for three years. Her business is located in a vibrant location, and her primary customers are of all types. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of capital. 

She will use the 50,000 Kenyan shillings loan to buy more stock of ingredients for preparing food for sale. Her business goal is to open a hotel within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will own a big hotel. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Her previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of ingredients for preparing food for selling

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more DVD's and CD's for resale.

loans.name: Denis

texts.en:
Denis is a married man. He has two children. He describes himself to be determined. He operates a transport business where he transports customers using his motorcycle. He has been involved in this business for five years. His business is located in a vibrant location, and his primary customers are of all types. He describes his biggest business challenge to be lack of capital. 

He will use the 20,000 Kenyan shillings loan to buy stock of groceries for his wife's grocery shop. His business goal is to own two motorcycles within five years. He hopes that in the future, he will own a tuk tuk. 

This is his second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. His previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy stock of groceries for his wife's grocery shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more stock of clothes to sell

loans.name: Dan

texts.en: Dan is a married man. He has 5 children with ages ranging from 8 years to 15 years. He describes himself as optimistic. He operates a transport business where he transports customers using his tuk tuk. He has been involved in this business for 5 years. His business is located in a busy area. He describes his biggest business challenge to be a lack of finances. He will use the KES10,000 loan to buy a motorcycle for his business. His business goal is to have a full transport company within 5 years. He hopes that he will have a quality life in the future. This is his second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. His previous loan was repaid successfully. He will use the anticipated profits to pay his bills.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en: Mary Ann is a married woman with six children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Mary Ann is 36 years old and has four children who are currently in school. She has a furniture making business in the Philippines. Mary Ann has requested a PHP 17,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase additional materials like bamboo, nails, paints, etc. for her business. She has been in this business for seven years. In the future, Mary Ann would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional materials like bamboo, nails, paints, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Carmenchita

texts.en:
Carmenchita is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a buy and sell charcoal business in the Philippines. She is borrowing 14,000 PHP through NWTF to buy sacks of charcoal to sell for her buy and sell charcoal business. Carmenchita has been in this business for two years.  She earns more income from buying and selling sweet potatoes and vegetables.

Carmenchita successfully paid back her previous loan and now she has requested an additional loan to further build her business. Carmenchita has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough money so she could afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to buy sacks of charcoal to sell for her business

loans.name: Rosanel

texts.en:
Rosanel works hard to support her family. Rosanel is married and has a food vending business in the Philippines. She requested a 13,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business. Rosanel has been in this business for two years now.

In the future, Rosanel would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Aida works hard to support her family.

She has a business farming vegetables in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from selling vegetables. Aida is borrowing 22,000 PHP through NWTF to buy additional sacks of fertilizer and other farm supplies for her farming business.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and now she has requested an additional loan to further build her business.

Aida has been sustaining her business activities through her past 12 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business in order to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional sacks of fertilizer and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Aluncia

texts.en:
As a married parent of 11 children, Aluncia works hard to support her family.

She has a business of farming rice in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buying and selling rice. Aluncia is borrowing 30,000 PHP through NWTF to buy additional sacks of fertilizer and other farm supplies for her farming business.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and now she has requested an additional loan to further build her business.

Aluncia has been sustaining her business activities through her past 17 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business in order to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional sacks of fertilizer and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Mukankindo

texts.en:
Esperance, age 30, is married with three children ages between 4 and 7 years, all of whom go to school. Her business is different items in her boutique, she has been running the business for the past two years. Her husband works as a businessman. 

With the loan, she would like to add more foodstuffs, such as beans and maize, to the existing retail business she has runs. The profit of the business will be used to reinvest in the same business for a better future.

loans.use: To add foodstuffs such as beans and maize.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is a female Ugandan living in Masindi. She has a salon business with cosmetics. She also farms in order to generate extra income. Monica hopes to educate her children to university despite the challenges of competition and high taxes imposed on her products especially cosmetics.

She will use the loan to buy cosmetics to use in her salon.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics to use in her salon.

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en:
Mwanaisha appreciates for the previous loan that helped her expand her business.

She has operates a kiosk retail shop business, selling household consumables like wheat flour, maize flour and sugar. She faces a major challenge of creditors taking too long to repay loans. 

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour

loans.name: Ros's Group

texts.en: Ros’s group live in a rural village in Kompong Thom province in Cambodia. Ros makes a living cultivating rice and she also does extra work as farm laborer to support her family.She has one youngest child in her family. In their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. Having a water filter at home will help each of these women to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: To buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.

loans.name: Karen Jacqueline

texts.es:
En la localidad conocida con el nombre de Pachinche  de la parroquia Colon de la ciudad de Portoviejo lugar conocido por su gente trabajadora y dedicada a la agricultura y la ganadería cada quince días se reúnen los socios del Grupo De Crédito Emprendedoras De Pachinche.
En este lugar vive la señora Karen, tiene 24 años de edad, mantiene una relación de unión libre y tienen una  hija de 4 meses de nacida la cual es su vida. Su esposo es agente vendedor.
Doña Karen es una mujer muy trabajadora que le ayuda a su marido con las ventas de material de ferretería que el vende, pero ella quiere instalar su propio negocio y es por eso que esta adecuando un local en su casa y con este crédito surtir  una pequeña tienda de víveres, cerca de su casa no hay tiendas por lo cual espera que le vaya muy bien, allí también espera vender productos de ferretería con lo cual ayudaría a su marido y ganaría algo para ella.
Este crédito lo va a emplear en comprar víveres para su tienda. Está en el Grupo De Crédito hace 4 ciclos y le gusta por la ayuda que siempre le dan en el grupo. Sus metas son que le vaya bien en su negocio.
texts.en:
In the place known as Pachinche in the Colon parish of the City of Portoviejo, the members of the communal bank "Emprendedoras de Pachinche" meet every 15 days.  This is a place where the people work raising livestock and farming.

This is where Karen, 24, lives.  She's in a common law marriage and has a 4 month-old daughter who is her entire life.  Her husband is a salesman. Karen is a very hardworking woman who helps her husband with his business selling hardware.  However, she wants to establish her own store, and so this is why she is setting up a shop in her home.  With this loan, she will stock up her small grocery store.  There are no stores near her house, and so this is why she hopes that her business will do very well.  In addition, she hopes to sell hardware products, which will help her husband and produce some extra income for her.

Karen will use this loan to buy food for her store.  She's been with her communal bank for 4 loan cycles and she likes it because of the assistance that is always provided by the group.  Her goal is to do well with her business.

loans.use: to buy food

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en:
This is Jacqueline. She is 34 years old and currently resides with her husband, Johnrey, in Manila, Philippines. She has been operating her own “sari-sari” (variety) store for more than three years, and she profits well from this. Having a bigger responsibility requires more effort to provide for her family's needs, especially for her children. She and her partner had to work hard, determined to have a better income, to provide their children with a better education.

In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages, piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To improve sales, Jacqueline would like to apply for a loan to purchase additional grocery goods to sell. At an amount of 10,000 PHP (Philippine Pesos), she could purchase larger quantities and more varieties of grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business. She sincerely lets you know her heartfelt thanks and appreciation for this assistance in advance.

In the future, Jacqueline hopes to maintain an increasing profit from her business. She dreams for her family to be always happy and healthy. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God, which she studies.

*All CCT (Center for Community Transformation Credit Cooperative) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed for her business.

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
Estrella is 58 years old and married with three children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 12,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy additional items for resale, such as shampoo, sugar, rice, groceries, etc.

Estrella has borrowed and paid nine loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for three years and also earns income from buying and selling dried fish.

She aspires to build and expand her business in order to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional items for resale, such as shampoo, sugar, rice and groceries.

loans.name: Victor Manuel

texts.es:
Víctor, es una persona que trabaja en el campo y ofrece sus servicios como albañil; está acompañado, vive con su compañera de vida y sus tres hijos de 19, 17 y  15 años de edad, sus hijos están estudiando; desempeña trabajos de agricultura desde hace 23 años, es un oficio que le enseño su padre y lo realiza en horario de 8:00 a.m. a 5:00 p.m.
Invertirá en la compra de insecticidas, abono, feriantes, etc. para la milpa, espera poder comercializar a buen precio los granos básicos que en este momento tiene almacenado y obtener una cosecha abundante para mantener su fuente de ingresos funcionando y cancelar la deuda.
Sus sueños son tener en el futuro cosechas más abundantes, mejores ingresos, estar libre de deudas y seguir velando por que  a su familia no le falte nada.
texts.en:
Victor is a field worker and serves as a contractor. He lives with his life partner and three children of ages 19,17,and 15. His children are in school. He has performed agriculture work since the age of 23. It is a job that his father taught him. His work schedule is from 8:00 AM to 5:00 PM. 

He will invest in the purchase of insecticides, fertilizer,street market stalls, etc. for the cornfield. He hopes to get good prices for the basic grains he has stored right now and have an abundant harvest to maintain his source of income and to settle his debt. His dreams are to have very abundant harvests in the future, a better income, be free of debt, and to continue providing so that his family will not be in need of anything.

loans.use: is to invest in the purchase of insecticides, fertilizer,street market stalls, etc. for the cornfield

loans.name: Erma

texts.en:
Erma is 31 years old and married with two children. With her children currently in school, Erma works very hard to provide for them.

Erma runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 12,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy more goods for resale, such as shampoo, detergent soap, noodles, biscuits, candies, cooking oil, etc. 

Erma has been in this business for six years and sells a variety of items, such as shampoo, detergent soap, noodles, biscuits, candies and cooking oil. 

In the future, Erma would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more goods for resale, such as shampoo, detergent soap, noodles, biscuits, candies and cooking oil.

loans.name: Jyotsna

texts.en:
Jyotsna is 38-year-old mother of two children (one son and one daughter) who are students. They are from the village of Tekatuli, located in West Bengal.  She is a hard-working, responsible woman with desires to improve herself. For lack of economic resources in her home, she was not able to finish her schooling, but this was not an obstacle to enter into her husband's business of selling cosmetics.

Jyotsna's husband, Prodyut, have a general store near their house. They sell shampoo, perfumes, creams, powder, eye liner, soaps, detergent etc. in their shop. Jyotsna assists her husband in the business. He started his business with his own funds and he has been working for years in this business. One of his dreams is to be able to grow his business and generate more income to strengthen his business and family economy.

Now Jyotsna wants to take a loan from Kiva's partner BJS. The goal of this loan is to buy more items for their business so that they can reach as many customers as possible and satisfy the demand of their customers, and thereby increase the volume of their sales and at the same time their income.

She wants to provide higher education to her children to establish them in life
.
She conveys her thanks to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase more items for their existing general store.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.es:
Daniel tiene de 20 años, es soltero, vive en casa de familiares, sin carga familiar; vive en una comunidad dedicada al comercio, agricultura y ganaderia, ubicada en el distrito de Saña, en la provincia de Chiclayo, región de Lambayeque, costa norte de Perú.

Daniel se dedica al servicio mototaxi principalmente pero también se dedica a la crianza de animales de corral, él necesita préstamo para invertir en el mantenimiento de su mototaxi y para comprar más animales para criarlos y luego venderlos, con esto tendrá mayores ingresos, ya que podrá dar atención a más clientes y de esta manera mejorarán sus ingresos y por ende también su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Daniel is 20 years old, single, and lives with relatives.  He has no dependents. He lives in a community dedicated to commerce, livestock production, and farming.  This area is in the Saña district of Chiclayo province, in the Lambayeque region of the northern coast of Peru.

Daniel's main business is providing moto-taxi transportation services, but he also raises farm animals.  He needs a loan to invest in maintenance work on his moto-taxi, and also to buy more animals to raise and later sell.  This way he will have more income, because he will be able to provide service to more customers, thereby increasing his earnings and quality of life.

loans.use: to maintain his moto-taxi and buy more animals to raise and sell

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny is 36 years old and married.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 22,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase additional household goods for resale, such as canned goods, eggs and noodles.

Jenny has borrowed and paid 17 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for eight years and also earns income from pig fattening and pre-paid mobile load.

She aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional household goods for resale, such as canned goods, eggs and noodles.

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Luz works hard to support her family.

She has a dried fish-selling business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from food vending. Luz is borrowing 18,000 PHP through NWTF to buy additional boxes of dried fish to sell.

Luz has sustained her business activities through her past 15 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of building and expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional boxes of dried fish to sell

loans.name: Ceferina

texts.en:
Ceferina works hard to support her family. Ceferina is married and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Ceferina requested a 14,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell in her general store.

Ceferina has been in this business for 25 years now.

She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Disery

texts.en:
Disery, 30, is a married woman with two children who are in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Disery has a business selling decorative items in the Philippines. Disery requested a 12,000 PHP loan amount through NWTF to purchase more goods to sell to her customers.

Disery has been in this business for 19 years. In the future, she would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more goods to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Mahran

texts.en: Mahran is a 26-year-old, married man. He studied until the elementary education. Unfortunately, he didn't complete his a studies. Now, he is an employee in a private sector with a small salary and lives with his family in a humble house in Taiz city, Yemen. The salary that he receives from his job is not enough to cover all the expenses of the family. He is a very vigorous and ambitious young man and works hard to improve the living condition of his family. The house where Mahran and his family live lacks many home appliances, and most of them are very old and need to be changed. Mahran and his family feel ashamed from this condition, especially if any guests come to visit the house. Mahran wants to make the necessary improvements for his house. Unfortunately, he doesn't have the enough money to do that. For this reason, Mahran applied for a Youth loan of 100,000 YER from AMB in order to purchase furniture for his house. Mahran looks forward to improving the living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to purchase furniture for his house.

loans.name: Julia Veronica

texts.es: Julia de 20 años de edad es madre soltera y habita en vivienda propia junto a su hija de 5 años de edad. Ella es una joven emprendedoras que todos los días se esfuerza por sacar adelante a su hija, por medio de su pequeña venta de tamales de gallina, dicha actividad la realiza desde hace 3 años por lo que ya cuenta con una buena cantidad de clientes que siempre esperan por sus productos. Julia desea construir un cuarto en su propiedad por lo que solicita un crédito a FUSAI para comprar: cemento, arena, bloques de cemento, grava y hierro, además pagará mano de obra para construir un cuarto en su propiedad.
texts.en:
Julia is a 20 year old single mother and lives in her own house with her 5 year old daughter. She is a young entrepreneur who strives daily to support her daughter by selling chicken tamales. She has been doing this job for the past 3 years thus she already has a good amount of customers that are always waiting for her products. 

Julia wishes to build a room in her house so she is applying for a FUSAI loan to buy cement, sand, cement blocks, gravel, and iron as well as to pay for labor to build a room in her house.

loans.use: to buy cement, sand, cement blocks, gravel, and iron as well as to pay for labor to build a room in her house.

loans.name: Arnold

texts.en: Arnold is 33 years old and lives in a town. There he has a small farm supplies store. He needs to stock different farm supplies to impact his customers. His challenge is to have sufficient working capital to achieve this, which is precisely the reason to use a Kiva loan. His first financing is through the ASKI, which he will use to buy feed, fertilizer and other farm supplies. He is always enthusiastic, because he knows his business is very young, but his family members are merchants as well, and he wishes to follow in the footsteps of his mother and grandmother.

loans.use: to buy feed, fertilizer and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen has been selling woven nipa (palm fronds) to make a living for many years while also watching over her retail store. She earns a good income from these activities and has successfully repaid her previous loans. Recently, she took a new loan to buy additional raw materials for nipa making. She is hoping that, with this business, the general living situation of her family will improve.

loans.use: to buy additional raw materials for nipa making

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy more stock of bananas.

loans.name: Maria Jessa

texts.en:
Maria Jessa works hard to support her family. Maria Jessa is married and has a buy and sell fish business in the Philippines. Maria Jessa has been in this business for eight years now.
